title: Belichick Strikes Again: Antonio Brown Is a Patriot
text:
At this point, I’m convinced that, if the world was on the verge of ending, Bill Belichick would sign the world to a non-guaranteed one-year deal.

Why not? After all, there’s a lot of upside to signing the world. Go to Hawaii any time you want. Skiing in the Alps. All the wine in Tuscany. The Grand Canyon! It could really be great.

If the world doesn’t work out, just cut it. Let the lousy world go play for the Jets.

All this is a long way of saying: They’ve done it again, maddeningly.

Belichick’s New England Patriots—supervillains supreme; the best NFL team of the 21st century; a franchise that makes the otherwise rational sports fan want to hit themselves over the head with a cast iron frying pan—have once more capitalized on Other People’s Mistakes, snagging a starry weapon for a team that already has plenty.

On Saturday afternoon, the defending Super Bowl champions reached an agreement with Antonio Brown, the seven-time Pro Bowl wide receiver who did everything besides pretend to be a tomato to get released by the pathetic Raiders.

Jon Gruden’s regret is now Tom Brady’s top target. It’s like getting kicked out of a highway motel…and into a five-star suite.

If I were a Raiders fan, I would put another grocery bag over the grocery bag that’s already been on my head for the past few years.

Is anyone surprised? This is what the Patriots do. I told you this would happen last week! Belichick, aka The Grumpy Lobster Boat Captain, runs a merciless shop with a clear ethos—it’s the Grumpy Captain’s way, or the highway.

Everyone knows the deal walking in, so Belichick doesn’t mind taking a gamble on a talented player whom an opponent has cast away. If it doesn’t work out, Grumpy Cap’n cuts bait and moves on.

Corey Dillon. Randy Moss. Josh Gordon. And now AB—on his way to Foxborough, Mass., after an unsuccessful summer residency in the souls of Gruden and Raiders GM Mike Mayock.

Antonio Brown, center, with Raiders coach Jon Gruden and general manager Mike Mayock, didn’t wind up playing a game in Oakland. Photo: Gerome Wright/Image of Sport/Newscom/Zuma Press

If you’re a Pats hater—and wow, are they legion—I can understand the frustration. It’s like watching a tycoon find a $100 bill on the street. The Patriots are a Bond movie where the villain wins in the end. They’re a “Star Wars” remake in which Luke Skywalker misses, and Darth Vader actually finishes building the Death Star.

Brown may have proven himself to be a handful during his nine seasons in Pittsburgh—and his 11 or so minutes in Oakland—but the former sixth-round draft choice from Central Michigan (which, incidentally, lost to Wisconsin 61-0 Saturday) remains one of the most electric players in football. He gives the Patriots the sort of dynamic threat they once had in Moss. He’s also just 31—less than half Brady’s age.

Conspiracy theories are rampant at the moment. One of the most common, unsubstantiated, possibly total nonsense theories is that Brown, traded in the off-season from Pittsburgh to Oakland, took one look at the crummy Raiders and said to himself: Uh-oh. I have to get out of here.

Thus the monthlong AB vs. Oakland drama that included a bout with cryotherapy-scorched feet, an outdated helmet imbroglio, an Instagram-launched confrontation with the general manager, and a very odd YouTube video released on Friday night featuring what sounded like a recorded phone call with Gruden.

Is Brown secretly a genius? Was he trying to make this happen all along? Was his very public, very modern unraveling a canny, three-moves-ahead maneuver to find his way to New England?

I don’t know. I don’t know what the takeaway is here. What do we tell the kids?

Let this be a lesson to you, young ‘uns: If you feud with your team, have a weird helmet problem, become a preseason headache, accumulate a ton of fines, you might just find yourself released…to catch touchdown passes in Super Bowl LIV from Tom Brady!

New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, right, chats with Antonio Brown after a game in 2016. Photo: Jared Wickerham/Associated Press

Amazingly, the Patriots kick off their season Sunday night hosting the Steelers, the team that dealt Brown to Oakland. Steelers fans were highly entertained by Brown’s fiasco in Oakland. Brown in New England is a nightmare. How remarkable would it have been to watch Brady and AB go to work against Pittsburgh?

Alas, Brown cannot play, because of strict NFL rules against exciting things happening in the first weekend of the season. (Did you watch Bears-Packers? My eyeballs are considering a malpractice suit against the league.)

Still, New England’s season hasn’t even started, and the Patriots have already won. The Grumpy Lobster Boat Captain has squinted into the salty Atlantic air and hauled in another brilliant catch. New England will be hard to stop on the way to a fourth straight Super Bowl appearance. If you’re sick of them, you probably should make alternative plans for the first weekend of February.

The Patriots already run the world. The rest of us are just living in it—until we wind up on the Jets. Or, possibly, the Raiders.

Write to Jason Gay at Jason.Gay@wsj.com
description: Bill Belichick’s New England Patriots have once more capitalized on Other People’s Mistakes, snagging star receiver Antonio Brown.
